Hearing.Directory: <table-of-content>C O N T E N T S</table-of-content> <Speakers>OPENING STATEMENTS</Speakers> <peopleSpeaker>The Honorable Bob Goodlatte</peopleSpeaker> <peopleinfo>Virginia Chairman Committee on the Judiciary</peopleinfo> <Witness>The Honorable Jerrold Nadler</Witness> <peopleinfo>New York Committee on the Judiciary</peopleinfo> <witnesses>WITNESSES</witnesses> <Witness>The Honorable Rod Rosenstein</Witness> <peopleinfo>Deputy Attorney General US Department of Justice Oral Statement Official Hearing Record</peopleinfo> <Doc-title>OVERSIGHT HEARING WITH DEPUTY ATTORNEY GENERAL ROD ROSENSTEIN</Doc-title> <hearing-info paraId="1" speaker="">The committee met, pursuant to call, at 10:07 a.m., in Room 2141, Rayburn House Office Building, Hon. Bob Goodlatte [chairman of the committee] presiding.</hearing-info> <hearing-info paraId="2" speaker="">Present: Representatives Goodlatte, Smith, Chabot, Issa, King, Gohmert, Jordan, Poe, Marino, Gowdy, Labrador, Farenthold, Collins, DeSantis, Buck, Ratcliffe, Gaetz, Johnson of Louisiana, Biggs, Rutherford, Handel, Nadler, Lofgren, Jackson Lee, Cohen, Johnson of Georgia, Deutch, Gutierrez, Bass, Jeffries, Cicilline, Swalwell, Lieu, Raskin, Jayapal, and Schneider.</hearing-info> <overview>Subcommittee on Crime, Terrorism, Homeland Security, and</overview> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker=""> Staff Present: Shelley Husband, Staff Director; Branden Ritchie, Deputy Staff Director; Zach Somers, Parliamentarian and General Counsel; Bobby Parmiter, Chief Counsel, Security, and Investigations; Monalisa Dugue, Minority Deputy Chief Counsel, Subcommittee on Crime, Terrorism, Homeland Security, and Investigations; Arya Hariharan, Minority Counsel; Matthew Morgan, Minority Professional Staff Member; and Veronica Eligan, Minority Professional Staff Member. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Goodlatte</speaker> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">Good morning. The Judiciary Committee will come to order. And without objection, the chair is authorized to declare recesses of the committee at any time.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">We welcome everyone to this morning's hearing on ``Oversight Hearing with Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein,'' and I'll begin by recognizing myself for an opening statement.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">Thank you, Deputy Attorney General Rosenstein, for appearing for the first time in front of this committee. There is much to discuss today, and we look forward to your testimony and answers to our questions.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">As chairman of the committee with primary oversight of the Department of Justice and the FBI, I have always supported the Department and the FBI in performing their valuable missions to keep our Nation safe and to hold individuals accountable for criminal conduct. Yet, I and many on this committee now find ourselves in the very difficult position of questioning the actions of both prior and current Department and FBI leadership.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">You have a unique role at the Department of Justice in that you appointed Special Counsel Mueller and have a supervisory role over his investigation. It is therefore very appropriate for you to appear before this committee to answer questions related to the scope of the special counsel's investigation, as well as its current efficacy in light of various events calling into question its impartiality.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">Reports on the political predisposition and potential bias of certain career agents and Department lawyers on Special Counsel Mueller's team are deeply troubling to all citizens who expect a system of blind and equal justice.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">The Department of Justice investigations must not be tainted by individuals imposing their own political prejudices. We are now beginning to better understand the magnitude of this insider bias on Mr. Mueller's team.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">First, we have FBI Agent Peter Strzok and FBI lawyer Lisa Page exchanging communications showing extreme bias against President Trump, a fact that would be bad enough if it weren't for the fact that these two individuals were employed as part of the Mueller ``Dream Team'' investigating the very person for whom they were showing disdain.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">And calling it mere disdain is generous. According to the documents produced last night to this committee, Mr. Strzok and Ms. Page referred to the President as an utter idiot, a loathsome human, and awful, while continually praising Hillary Clinton and the Obamas.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">These text messages prove what we all suspected: High ranking FBI officials involved in the Clinton investigation were personally invested in the outcome of the election and clearly let their strong political opinions cloud their professional judgment. And this was only an initial disclosure containing heavy reductions.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">Second, former embattled FBI general counsel and current Mueller prosecutor Andrew Weissmann expressed his awe of a former DOJ official for shunning the President and failing to faithfully execute the law. However, we are the ones now in awe that someone like Mr. Weissmann remains on an investigative team that looks more and more partisan.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">Third, we have learned that a top Mueller prosecutor, Jeannie Rhee, in addition to the other actions that would normally justify recusal, served as an attorney for the Clinton Foundation. Aren't Department of Justice attorneys advised to avoid even the appearance of impropriety? A former Clinton employee is now investigating President Trump. This seems to be the very definition of appearance of impropriety.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">Fourth, we have just recently learned that another top Department of Justice official, Bruce Ohr, has been reassigned because of his wife and his connections with the infamous dossier and the company from whom the opposition research document originated.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">We hope to hear your assessment of the foregoing conflicts, whether individuals are being held accountable, and whether you still have confidence in the judgment of the special counsel you named and supervised.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">Regarding the Clinton email scandal, you, along with Attorney General Sessions, have to date declined to appoint a second special counsel to investigate the improprieties that continue to surface related to the handling of the Clinton email investigation and other events surrounding the 2016 election.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">These are some of the important issues on which we will focus our energy and questions today. We want to understand your participation and the Department's involvement in addressing both investigations.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">Mr. Deputy Attorney General, the Department of Justice's reputation as an impartial arbiter of justice has been called into question. This taint of politicization should concern all Americans who have pride in the fairness of our Nation's justice system.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">While we continue to call on you to appoint a second special counsel, as you are aware, we have also opened our own joint investigation with the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee to review FBI and the Department of Justice's handling of the Clinton email investigation.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="22" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">I want to thank you and Attorney General Sessions for recently committing to provide us relevant documents to enable robust congressional oversight of this matter. I implore you to continue to work with us on these and other important matters facing our Nation.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="23" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">One of these matters involves a critical program for our national security, FISA Section 702. This committee passed on an overwhelming bipartisan basis the USA Liberty Act which maintains the integrity of the program while protecting cherished civil liberties. This overwhelming vote occurred despite the Department's lobbying efforts against our bill.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="24" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">The USA Liberty Act was characterized as bad for the program, highly problematic, unworkable, and a proposal that would effectively dismantle Section 702. However, the reality is that this committee's legislation struck a balance that promotes national security and civil liberties.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="25" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">I hope to hear from you why the Department of Justice felt it necessary to oppose a bill that would reauthorize 702 and instill confidence in the American people that their privacy and civil liberties are respected by a government whose duty it is to protect them.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="26" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">The Department of Justice must reacquire the trust of the American people. I know there are thousands of Department of Justice employees and line agents in the Federal Bureau of Investigations that are dedicated individuals that are dedicated to upholding the rule of law and protecting the American people, and I hope that we can come to a conclusion about those people who have not met that standard in this hearing today.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="27" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">Thank you, Mr. Deputy Attorney General, for appearing today.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="28" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte"> I now yield to the gentleman from New York, the ranking member of the committee, Mr. Nadler, for his comments. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Nadler</speaker> <paragraph paraId="29" speaker="Mr. Nadler">Thank you, Mr. Chairman.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="30" speaker="Mr. Nadler">Before I begin my statement, first, let me wholly endorse the comments of the chairman with reference to Section 702 and to the legislation that we reported out of this committee.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="31" speaker="Mr. Nadler">And second, I want to acknowledge a letter the chairman and I received last night from the Democratic women of this committee. Our colleagues have written to ask that we convene a hearing regarding the serious and credible allegations of sexual harassment and misconduct leveled against President Trump by at least 19 women.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="32" speaker="Mr. Nadler"> Without objection, I ask that this letter be made part of the record. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Goodlatte</speaker> <paragraph paraId="33" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte"> Without objection, it will be made part of the record. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Nadler</speaker> <paragraph paraId="34" speaker="Mr. Nadler">And let me be clear, I unequivocally endorse this letter. We should convene this hearing as soon as possible. This is an opportunity for us to lead and to show the country that this kind of behavior is unacceptable at any level of government.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="35" speaker="Mr. Nadler">Mr. Chairman, let me start by saying welcome to the House Judiciary Committee, Mr. Rosenstein. For the better part of a year, my colleagues and I have implored this committee to conduct real oversight of the Department of Justice.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="36" speaker="Mr. Nadler">On January 24, 2017, we wrote to Chairman Goodlatte insisting that the committee hold hearings on President Trump's conflicts of interest at home and abroad. Citing to experts across the political spectrum, we show that, quote, ``The administration's attempts to address its ongoing conflicts of interest are so far wholly inadequate,'' close quote.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="37" speaker="Mr. Nadler">Six weeks later, Attorney General Sessions was forced to recuse himself from the Russia investigation, but we have not held a single hearing on the question of conflicts of interest. On March 8, we wrote again to the chairman encouraging him to call hearings on, quote, ``Russia's alleged interference in the U.S. election.'' Again, no such hearings were ever held.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="38" speaker="Mr. Nadler">In fact, this committee, which during the Obama administration held half a dozen hearings around Operation Fast and Furious, received testimony from FBI Director Comey three times in 13 months and detailed staff and resources to a Benghazi investigation that cost the public almost $8 million.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="39" speaker="Mr. Nadler">This committee, from inauguration day until 4 weeks ago, was largely silent in terms of oversight. We haven't lifted a finger on election security. Attorney General Sessions told us on November 14 that he has done nothing to secure the next election from threats from at home and abroad.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="40" speaker="Mr. Nadler">We have not once discussed the President's abuse of the pardon power. While the hurricane bore down on Houston, President Trump sidelined the Office of the Pardon Attorney to pardon a serial human rights abuser who bragged about running a concentration camp in Arizona.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="41" speaker="Mr. Nadler">And we have not held a single hearing on allegations of obstruction of justice at the White House, not for lack of evidence, but because, in the chairman's words, quote, ``There is a special counsel in place examining the issue,'' unquote, and quote, ``Several other congressional committees are looking into the matter,'' and the committee, quote, ``does not have the time to conduct this critical oversight.'' I ask my colleagues to keep those excuses in mind.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="42" speaker="Mr. Nadler">Now, with the year coming to a close, with the leadership of the Department of Justice finally before us, what do my Republican colleagues want to discuss? Hillary Clinton's emails.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="43" speaker="Mr. Nadler">Let me repeat that. With all of these unresolved issues left on our docket, a week before we adjourn for the calendar year the majority's highest oversight priority is Hillary Clinton's emails and a few related text messages.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="44" speaker="Mr. Nadler">As we saw in our recent hearings with the Department of Justice and the FBI, my Republican colleagues seem singularly focused on their call for a second special counsel, and failing that, on the need to investigate the investigators ourselves.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="45" speaker="Mr. Nadler">The White House has now joined the call by House Republicans for a new special counsel to investigate the FBI. The President's private lawyers have done the same. I understand the instinct to want to change the subject after the Flynn and Manafort indictments, but this request is grossly misguided for a number of reasons.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="46" speaker="Mr. Nadler">First, it shows a fundamental misunderstanding of how the special counsel regulations work. Some criminal investigations pose a conflict of interest to the Department of Justice. The Russia investigation is such a case because of the Attorney General's ongoing recusal and because Department leadership assisted in the removal of Director Comey, among other reasons. In cases like these, the Attorney General may use a special counsel to manage the investigation outside of the ordinary chain of command.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="47" speaker="Mr. Nadler">But the key here is the criminal investigation. That's what special counsel does. The Department cannot simply assign a special counsel to look at things that bother the White House. There has to be enough evidence to have predicated a criminal investigation in the first place. Then and only then, if the facts warrant, can a special counsel be assigned to the case.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="48" speaker="Mr. Nadler">So far, there's been no credible factual or legal claim that anybody at the Department of Justice violated any law by deciding not to bring charges against Hillary Clinton or by attempting to meet with Fusion GPS. In other words, there is no investigation to which the Department could even assign a new special counsel.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="49" speaker="Mr. Nadler">Second, the list of grievances raised by the majority for review by a new special counsel also seems wildly off the mark. For example, there is nothing unlawful about Director Comey sitting down to draft an early statement about the Clinton investigation. Nor would it have been unethical to outline his conclusions before the investigation was over if the clear weight of the evidence pointed in one direction. Nor is there anything wrong with FBI agents expressing their private political views via private text messages, as Peter Strzok and Lisa Page appeared to have done in the 375 text messages we received last night. In fact, Department regulations expressly permit that sort of private communication.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="50" speaker="Mr. Nadler">I've reviewed those text messages and I'm left with two thoughts.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="51" speaker="Mr. Nadler">First, Peter Strzok did not say anything about Donald Trump that the majority of Americans weren't also thinking at the same time.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="52" speaker="Mr. Nadler">And second, in a testament to his integrity and situational awareness, when the Office of the Inspector General made Mr. Mueller aware of these exchanges, he immediately removed Mr. Strzok from his team.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="53" speaker="Mr. Nadler">To the extent that we are now engaged in oversight of political bias at the FBI, this committee should examine evidence of a coordinated effort by some agents involved in the Clinton investigation to change the course of the campaign in favor of President Trump by leaking sensitive information to the public and by threatening to leak additional information about new emails after the investigation was closed.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="54" speaker="Mr. Nadler">On Monday, Ranking Member Cummings and I sent a letter to the Department asking for additional materials related to these leaks, as well as to the claims that these efforts may have been coordinated with former Mayor Rudy Giuliani, former National Security Advisor Michael Flynn, and other senior figures in the Trump campaign.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="55" speaker="Mr. Nadler">Third, the President's call for an investigation of the investigation is at best wildly dangerous to our democratic institutions. On the one hand, the President's old ``lock her up'' cheer seems quaint after a couple of guilty pleas by Trump associates.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="56" speaker="Mr. Nadler">On the other, as former Attorney General Michael Mukasey, no fan of Hillary Clinton, has said, the President's continued threats to prosecute his political opponents is, quote, ``something we don't do here.'' If the President were to carry out his threat, quote, again from Attorney General Mukasey, ``it would be like a banana republic.''</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="57" speaker="Mr. Nadler">Finally, and most important, this investigation into the investigation cannot credibly be a priority for this committee at this time. I understand the instinct to want to give cover to the President. I am fearful that the majority's effort to turn the tables on the special counsel will get louder and more frantic as the walls continue to close in around the President.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="58" speaker="Mr. Nadler">But this committee has a job to do. President Trump has engaged in a persistent and dangerous effort to discredit both the free press and the Department of Justice. These are the agencies and institutions under our jurisdiction.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="59" speaker="Mr. Nadler">Every minute that our majority wastes on covering for President Trump is a minute lost on finding a solution for the DREAMers, or curbing a vicious spike in hate crimes, or preventing dangerous individuals from purchasing firearms, or stopping the President from further damaging the constitutional order.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="60" speaker="Mr. Nadler">I hope my colleagues will use today's hearing as an opportunity to find their way back to the true work of the House Judiciary Committee.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="61" speaker="Mr. Nadler"> I thank the chairman, and I yield back the balance of my time. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Goodlatte</speaker> <paragraph paraId="62" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">We welcome our distinguished witness. If you would please rise, I will begin by swearing you in.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="63" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte"> Do you solemnly swear that the testimony that you are about to give shall be the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth, so help you God? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Rosenstein</speaker> <paragraph paraId="64" speaker="Mr. Rosenstein"> I do. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Goodlatte</speaker> <paragraph paraId="65" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">Thank you.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="66" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">Let the record show that the witness answered in the affirmative.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="67" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">Mr. Rod Rosenstein was sworn in as the 37th Deputy Attorney General of the United States on April 26, 2017, by Attorney General Jeff Sessions. Mr. Rosenstein has had a distinguished career in public service. He began his legal career in the Public Integrity Section of the Department of Justice's Criminal Division and later served as counsel to the Deputy Attorney General and Principal Deputy Assistant General for the Tax Division.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="68" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">Until his appointment by President Trump, Mr. Rosenstein served for 12 years as the United States attorney for the District of Maryland. He holds a bachelor's degree in economics from the Wharton School and a JD from Harvard Law School.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="69" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">General Rosenstein, your written statement will be entered into the record in its entirety, and we ask that you summarize your testimony in 5 minutes.</paragraph>
Hearing.Statement: <opening>TESTIMONY OF HONORABLE ROD ROSENSTEIN, DEPUTY ATTORNEY GENERAL,U.S. DEPARTMENT OF JUSTICE</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="TESTIMONY OF HONORABLE ROD ROSENSTEIN">Welcome. We're pleased to have you here.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="TESTIMONY OF HONORABLE ROD ROSENSTEIN"> U.S. DEPARTMENT OF JUSTICE </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Rosenstein</speaker> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Rosenstein">Chairman Goodlatte, Ranking Member Nadler, members of the committee, I want to thank you for this opportunity to testify as part of your oversight of the United States Department of Justice. I appreciate your support and concern for the Department of Justice. I know several of you are alumni of the Department. Two, in fact, served alongside me as United States attorneys. And I'm very grateful for the opportunity to be with you today.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Rosenstein">As Deputy Attorney General, my job is to help the Attorney General to manage our Department's components, including 7 Main Justice litigating divisions, 94 U.S. Attorney's Offices, the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Drug Enforcement Administration, the Bureau of Alcohol Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, the United States Marshals Service, the Office of Justice Programs, the Federal Bureau of Prisons, the Office of the Inspector General, and many others.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Mr. Rosenstein">Our Department includes over 115,000 employees and tens of thousands of contractors stationed in every State and territory and in many foreign nations.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Mr. Rosenstein">We prevent terrorism and violent crime, illegal drug distribution, fraud, corruption, child abuse, civil rights violations, and countless other threats to the American people.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Mr. Rosenstein">We enforce tax laws, antitrust laws, and environmental laws. We represent the United States in the Supreme Court, the Courts of Appeal, and the District Courts, and in State and territorial courts. We protect Federal judges, manage Federal prisons, review parole applications, oversee the bankruptcy system.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Mr. Rosenstein">We assist Tribal governments and we adjudicate immigration cases. We provide legal advice to the President and to every Federal agency. We implement grant programs and support State and local law enforcement. We combat waste fraud and other misconduct involving employees and contractors.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Mr. Rosenstein">We resolve foreign claims and represent our government in international law enforcement forums. We collect, analyze, and disseminate law enforcement data.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Mr. Rosenstein">And we perform countless other important functions for the American people.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Mr. Rosenstein">Department of Justice employees are united by a shared understanding that our mission is to pursue justice, protect public safety, preserve government property, defend civil rights, and promote the rule of law.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Mr. Rosenstein">The mission attracted me to law enforcement, but the people who carry out that mission are what I treasure most about my job. With very few exceptions, they are honorable, principled, and trustworthy.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Mr. Rosenstein">America's Federal, State, and local law enforcement agencies are more professional today than ever. Rigorous scrutiny by internal affairs offices and external oversight agencies has resulted in increased accountability and higher standards. When wrongdoing occurs, we are more likely to discover it and we remedy it. That is critical to building and maintaining public confidence.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Mr. Rosenstein">Over the past 8 months, I've spoken with thousands of Department employees around the country. I remind them that justice is not only our name, justice is our mission. Justice requires a fair and impartial process. That's why we have a special responsibility to follow ethical and professional standards.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Mr. Rosenstein">In 1941, Attorney General Robert Jackson said that the citizen's safety lies in the prosecutor who tempers zeal with human kindness, seeks truth and not victims, serves the law and not factional purposes, and approaches the task with humility.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Mr. Rosenstein">Under the leadership of Attorney General Jeff Sessions and an experienced team appointed by President Trump, the Department of Justice is working tirelessly to protect American citizens and to uphold the rule of law.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Mr. Rosenstein">Today I look forward to discussing some of our Department's important work. Following the U.S. Attorney's Manual and the example set by past Department of Justice officials, we always seek to accommodate congressional oversight requests while protecting the integrity of our investigations, preserving the Department's independence, and safeguarding sensitive information.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Mr. Rosenstein"> Thank you, Mr. Chairman. I look forward to your questions. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Goodlatte</speaker> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">Thank you, Mr. Rosenstein. I'll start by recognizing myself for questions.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">Last week Director Wray indicated that the normal procedures were not followed in the investigation of former Secretary Clinton's email server. It said it was not normal protocol to have witnesses sit in the room during an interview of the target of an investigation.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte"> If the inspector general determines that normal protocol was not followed or that the investigation was closed or otherwise tainted for political purposes, would that be a justification, in your mind, to reopen the investigation? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Rosenstein</speaker> <paragraph paraId="22" speaker="Mr. Rosenstein"> Mr. Chairman, we are certainly anticipating the outcome of that inspector general investigation. As you know, that's been ongoing for some time. I'm hopeful that it will be concluded within the next couple of months. And when we get those results we'll take appropriate action. I don't know exactly what the findings are going to be, but it's always appropriate for us to review any findings of impropriety or misconduct and take appropriate action. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Goodlatte</speaker> <paragraph paraId="23" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte"> When you announced your decision to terminate the employment of FBI Director Comey, in that decision you announced some practices that I took it to mean you thought were inappropriate actions on the part of former FBI Director. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Rosenstein</speaker> <paragraph paraId="1329" speaker="Mr. Rosenstein"> I have counsel in the FBI, and I have confidence, Mr. Chairman, that Director Wray will make appropriate decisions with regard to his staff. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Goodlatte</speaker> <paragraph paraId="1330" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">And finally, in an interview with NBC Scott MacFarlane on December 6, you indicated that you were satisfied with how the special counsel's investigation is proceeding.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="1331" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte"> Why, after you've heard all the concerns expressed here today, why are you satisfied with the course of the investigation so far? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Rosenstein</speaker> <paragraph paraId="1332" speaker="Mr. Rosenstein"> I'm satisfied, Congressman, because based upon what I know, which is different from what accounts may appear in the media, based upon what I know, I believe Director Mueller is appropriately remaining within his scope and conducting himself appropriately, and in the event that there is any credible allegation of misconduct by anybody on his staff, that he is taking appropriate action. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Goodlatte</speaker> <paragraph paraId="1333" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">Thank you. Thank you very much.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="1334" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">We will have, I have no doubt, from both sides of the aisle, additional questions in writing, and we hope that you're able to answer those and answer them expeditiously.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="1335" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">Again, I thank you. You're a little bit ahead, not much, but a little bit ahead of Director Wray's time. And I know the sacrifice it is to prepare for this and then to give us the better part of a day to answer these questions, but they are very important.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="1336" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">The FBI is an incredibly important law enforcement organization. In my opinion, it is still the premier law enforcement organization in the world. And again, as I said earlier, there are tens of thousands of employees there who are very dedicated to doing the right thing, upholding the rule of law, and providing justice in the fashion that the blindfolded woman with balanced scales stands for. I think the Department stands for that. But I do think at the higher levels of the Department, there are some serious problems.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="1337" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">The gentleman from Florida asked some questions very much related to this, and I think that while we all have confidence in Director Wray, we also believe that there need to be some changes made, both in terms of the personnel, in terms of the protocols that are followed, and certainly, in terms of getting the necessary information to this committee and whatever other appropriate committees so that all of this can be aired and the public's understanding that these problems are being solved, and that they know what the nature of them are.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="1338" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte"> So, again, thank you very much for your participation. Thank you very much for your work in a very difficult situation as Deputy Attorney General of the United States under these circumstances. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Rosenstein</speaker> <paragraph paraId="1339" speaker="Mr. Rosenstein"> Thank you. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Goodlatte</speaker> <paragraph paraId="1340" speaker="Chairman Goodlatte">And with that, without objection, all members will have 5 legislative days to submit additional written additional questions for the witness and additional materials for the record.
